G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This is an action brought by the Plaintiff, Jordan Harris, against Defendant, Linda Smith, for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as this action relates to violations of laws governing residential tenancies in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the property in question is located in Roxbury, within the territorial jurisdiction of the Boston Housing Court.

105 CMR 410.020 et seq..proposition: Massachusetts housing codes require landlords to maintain rental premises in a safe, habitable, and sanitary condition.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 18.proposition: Plaintiff contends that the decision not to renew the lease constitutes retaliation in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 18, given its proximity in time to Plaintiff’s engagement with housing inspectors.

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.proposition: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 417 Mass. 273 (1994) (interpreting covenant of quiet enjoyment).
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely analyzes and applies the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment in G.L. c. 186, § 14, to the tenants’ claim that the landlord’s failure to address criminal activity in common areas interfered with their tenancy. The court explains the scope of the covenant, the standard (“natural and probable consequence” of what the landlord did or failed to do), and holds that the plaintiffs stated a viable quiet enjoyment claim, reversing summary judgment. That is sufficient to say the case interprets the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.relevant_excerpt: “3. Covenant of quiet enjoyment. The plaintiffs argue that the judge erred in granting summary judgment in favor of the defendant on their claim that the defendant violated G. L. c. 186, § 14 (1992 ed.), the so-called ‘quiet enjoyment’ statute. … The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’”}

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (landlord's failure to address water intrusion).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely concerns a landlord’s repeated failure over several years to correct severe water (and sewage) intrusion into a tenant’s basement apartment. The court discusses the landlord’s duty under the warranty of habitability and quiet enjoyment, and upholds liability (including for emotional distress) based in part on evidence that the landlord knew of recurrent flooding and failed to take permanent corrective measures (e.g., cementing a porous wall) to prevent water from entering. Thus it is good authority for a proposition involving a landlord’s failure to address water intrusion.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “There was evidence at trial that the wall between Solomon’s apartment and the adjoining basement area was extremely porous. There was also testimony suggesting that Gem may have considered cementing the wall to prevent floods, but never carried out this plan. The jury could reasonably conclude that Gem’s failure to do so caused Solomon’s injuries… Further, a section of the State Sanitary Code… provides that apartments must be watertight… Having recognized that an inference was warranted that Gem failed in its duty to prevent the flooding, we find ample evidence… that Gem… thereby caused Solomon severe emotional harm.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979) (habitability standards and housing code violations).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion directly concerns the implied warranty of habitability in a residential lease and ties that warranty to compliance with the State Sanitary Code. The court holds that substantial Sanitary Code violations (here, loss of heat and hot water) constitute material breaches of the warranty of habitability and justify rent abatement from the time of notice, regardless of landlord fault. Thus, it is properly cited for habitability standards and the significance of housing code (Sanitary Code) violations.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “‘[A] lease is essentially a contract between the landlord and the tenant wherein the landlord promises to deliver and maintain the demised premises in habitable condition and the tenant promises to pay rent for such habitable premises. These promises constitute interdependent and mutual considerations.’… A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. … The rent abatement begins when notice is given, not at a reasonable time after notice.”

Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.raw_text: Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.proposition: Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (recognizing tenant remedies for unsafe conditions).
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.support_reasoning: Even in this partial concurrence/dissent, Justice Quirico expressly agrees that the court recognizes new tenant remedies tied to unsafe and substandard conditions, namely that the tenant’s rent liability is reduced to the reasonable value of the unit in light of sanitary code violations and that the landlord has an implied obligation to meet minimum habitability standards. While he disagrees with using a broad ‘implied warranty of habitability’ theory, he concurs in the core holding that tenants have a contract-based remedy when conditions are unsafe or code-deficient. Thus the case does recognize tenant remedies for unsafe conditions.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.relevant_excerpt: “The opinion of the court holds that the tenants are subject to eviction because of their failure to pay rent, but that their liability for unpaid rent is limited to the reasonable value, if any, of their apartments, considering the alleged violations of the Code. That holding is sufficient to dispose of the only issues raised in these cases, and to that extent I concur with the opinion. … I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards….”

Longwood Towers Corp. v. Doyle, 267 Mass.raw_text: Longwood Towers Corp. v. Doyle, 267 Mass. 368 (1929)
Longwood Towers Corp. v. Doyle, 267 Mass.proposition: Longwood Towers Corp. v. Doyle, 267 Mass. 368 (1929) (tenant rights to habitable premises).
Longwood Towers Corp. v. Doyle, 267 Mass.support_reasoning: The case concerns whether the tenant was constructively evicted and thus could withhold rent; the court holds there was no constructive eviction and that the tenant’s only remedy, if any, was an action for damages. It does not recognize or discuss a general tenant right to habitable premises or an implied warranty of habitability; instead it reiterates older property rules limiting the landlord’s repair obligations. Citing this case as authority for broad tenant rights to habitable premises misstates its holding and thrust.
Longwood Towers Corp. v. Doyle, 267 Mass.relevant_excerpt: "It is also to be observed that there is no evidence that the conditions of alleged uninhabitability existed or were known to the lessor to exist when the premises were leased, nor that the lessor did not remove the causes of the several complaints within a reasonable time after notice of them. Whatever duty, if any, rested upon the lessor to repair did not require it to keep the premises in good order at all times as respects temporary or incidental defects, and the defendant had no right to quit the premises and refuse to pay rent according to her covenant. Her remedy, if any, was by an action for damages."

Dol-Tek, Inc. v. Ramsey, 82 Mass. App. C.raw_text: Dol-Tek, Inc. v. Ramsey, 82 Mass. App. Ct. 648 (2012)
Dol-Tek, Inc. v. Ramsey, 82 Mass. App. C.proposition: Dol-Tek, Inc. v. Ramsey, 82 Mass. App. Ct. 648 (2012) (landlord liability for property damage).
Dol-Tek, Inc. v. Ramsey, 82 Mass. App. C.case_name: Jenzabar, Inc. v. Long Bow Group, Inc.
Dol-Tek, Inc. v. Ramsey, 82 Mass. App. C.support_reasoning: The provided text is a dissent focused entirely on Lanham Act trademark infringement and ‘initial interest confusion’ in the context of Internet search results. It does not address landlord–tenant law, property damage, or landlord liability in any way. Therefore, citing Dol-Tek, Inc. v. Ramsey for a proposition about landlord liability for property damage is inaccurate and unsupported by this opinion.
Dol-Tek, Inc. v. Ramsey, 82 Mass. App. C.relevant_excerpt: I dissent from the majority’s holding that the Lanham Act is not violated by Long Bow’s confusing use of Jenzabar’s trademark. Therefore, I dissent from the affirmance of summary judgment.

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987) (retaliatory actions by a landlord violate tenant rights).
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a tenant’s counterclaims for code violations, improper security deposit handling, rent control overcharges, and breach of warranty of habitability. It does not address retaliatory conduct by a landlord (e.g., retaliation for complaints or asserting rights) or articulate any rule about retaliatory actions violating tenant rights. The proposition about retaliatory actions by a landlord is therefore not supported by this case.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt:
This is the third of a series of summary process actions brought in the Housing Court by the landlord, Young. Judgment of possession was entered eventually for the tenant, Patukonis, on November 15, 1984. The tenant, however, appeals from the judgment, claiming that the trial judge improperly dismissed two of her six counterclaims and awarded inadequate damages on those claims upon which she ultimately prevailed.
...
Young, as an owner-occupant of a three-family building, whose primary objective is personal, is not subject to G. L. c. 93A. That claim was properly dismissed.
